required_header.download_date: ClinicalTrials.gov processed this data on May 29, 2018
required_header.link_text: Link to the current ClinicalTrials.gov record.

clinical_study.brief_title: Phototherapy in Persons With Multiple Sclerosis
clinical_study.official_title: Effect of UVB Phototherapy on Serum Vitamin D in Persons With Multiple Sclerosis; a Placebo Controlled Study

brief_summary.textblock: The current study examines the effect of phototherapy equipped with Narrow Band UVB lamps on vitamin D production in persons with MS.

detailed_description.textblock: Participants will be exposed to phototherapy according to the 2014 Guidelines issued by the American Academy of Dermatology 3 days per week over an 8-week period.

primary_outcome.measure: Change from Baseline in Serum Vitamin D at 4 and 8 weeks
primary_outcome.description: Venous blood will be collected to quantify levels of circulating Vitamin D.

secondary_outcome.measure: Change from Baseline in Walking Speed at 4 and 8 weeks
secondary_outcome.description: Participants will walking for 25-feet as fast, but safely, as possible on an instrumented gait mat for measuring gait speed.

secondary_outcome.measure: Change from Baseline in Cognitive Function at 4 and 8 weeks
secondary_outcome.description: Participants will complete neuropsychological assessments of processing speed and learning and memory.

secondary_outcome.measure: Change from Baseline in Mood State at 4 and 8 weeks
secondary_outcome.description: Participants will complete a 30-item self-report measure of overall mood.

arm_group.description: This arm involves exposure to a UVB phototherapy device 3 times per week over 8 weeks.
This arm is identical with experimental arm, except that participants will be exposed to non-UVB florescent light.

intervention.description: Participants will be exposed to phototherapy according to the 2014 Guidelines issued by the American Academy of Dermatology 3 days per week over an 8-week period.

criteria.textblock:
Inclusion Criteria:
- Female with multiple sclerosis
Exclusion Criteria:
- Inability to stand still in a stabilized fashion without risk of falling for up to 6 minutes
- Known medical history of calcium disorder or knowledge of high calcium levels
- Known medical history of hyper-parathyroidism
- Current supplementation with oral vitamin D
- Known allergy to vitamin D
- History of cancer of any type including but not limited to skin cancer
- Obesity defined as BMI > 30
- Known history of fat malabsorption conditions (i.e., steatorrhea)
- Current use of anti-epileptic medication
- Current use of glucocorticoids
- Fitzpatrick skin types I and VI using the Fitzpatrick skin type analysis
- Recent use of tanning facilities
